A big pet peeve of mine is when people pronounce Tokyo as "toe-key-yo." There's no "ee" sound in Tokyo. Just read it: To-kyo. See that "kyo?" It's like "qu" but with an "oh" at the end instead of an "oo". It's such a common mispronunciation at this point, so fighting it is probably useless, but man would I love it if at least the Scishow team could avoid it.

(My other big pet peeve is tsunami without the T-sound).

airplanes are not magnetic. I love you guys, and my favorite show on YouTube, but that magnetic field would do nothing to non-ferrous aluminum airplanes.

My theory with the bees (I'm an animal behaviourist but not so much involved with bees even though they are awesome!) is that their communication was hindered so more bees didn't leave the hive. The bees use arguably the coolest communication technique, including the waggle dance. This needs the sun and its direction to allow bees to convey to other bees what a food source is. If the sun suddenly disappears, the communication may just cease thus less bees leave the hive. Also, the bees currently out buzzing away may hunker down and hide, conserving their energy instead of flying around aimlessly as their navigation is taken away.

I'mm'a be a bit pedantic here but it's just because the physics is too cool not to share. A magnet that strong the size of a watch battery still couldn't lift an airplane because a) aluminum is only very weakly paramagnetic and b) magnetic saturation. An airplane's skin isn't thick enough for a magnetic field that strong to attract it strongly enough to lift the whole airplane because not enough magnetic field can saturate the volume of the skin. It's also the reason why big (and super strong) neodymium magnets can't stick to fridge doors much more powerfully than smaller neo magnets. The thin steel doors saturate and the excess magnetic field can't do anything. :D

But in the spirit of what Hank Green said, let's say we have a mass of something ferromagnetic (iron, nickel, cobalt, whatever; we basically need something that will happily stick to our magnet) equivalent to that of an airplane, and this is a solid mass with tons of volume for field saturation capacity, then it'll totally stick to said magnet and be lifted right up. :)

When you are learning English as a second language, it takes a long time to understand and assimilate organically the mechanisms behind properly using suffixes like the comparative ER or the superlative (I)EST. Hard to see all that time becoming meaningless with people trowing words like "magnetic-iest" at you in a SCIENCE show. Please, don't get me wrong, I just think ESL students would have a much better time if TOEFL just accepted these easier constructs as correct.
